Earlier in his career, while Latvia was still part of the
Soviet Union
, Andris Piebalgs worked as a teacher and was the headmaster of the 1st Secondary School of Valmiera (1980–1990).

Andris Piebalgs is a Latvian politician and diplomat who served as
European Commissioner for Development
at the
European Commission
from 2010 until 2014.

Between 2004 and 2009 he served as
Commissioner for Energy
.

Between 4 June 2016 and 19 August 2017, he served as the leader of the
Unity
party.

Andris Piebalgs
(born 17 September 1957) is a Latvian politician and diplomat who served as

Andris Piebalgs was born on 17 September 1957 in
Valmiera
, Latvia.
a member of Communist Party of Soviet Union from 1979.
In 1988, Latvian People's Front, an organisation that united more than 200,000 people, was established.
Supporters of Latvian self-determination gained victory in the March 1990 parliamentary election.
On 7 May 1990, Andris Piebalgs was appointed as Minister of Education in the new Government,
one year later, in August 1991, Latvia regained full independence.
In 1993, Andris Piebalgs won a seat in the Latvian Parliament,
He served as the chairman of the budget and finance committee until 1994.
In September 1994, he became Latvia's Minister of Finance and deputy prime minister.
From 1995 until 2003, he worked in the Latvian Diplomatic service.
Andris Piebalgs first served as the ambassador of Latvia in Estonia (1995–1997),
In 1997 he became the Latvian Ambassador to the EU.
which resulted in Latvia's successful accession to the EU in 2004.
From 2003 to 2004, he was appointed Deputy Secretary of State for EU affairs at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Latvia.
During the first Barroso Commission, starting in November 2004, he was the European Commissioner for Energy.

2007. In 2009, Andris Piebalgs received the 'Diamond Prize' from the Regional Chamber of Commerce in Katowice (Poland) for his work in developing a cohesive European Energy Policy for the further generations.

In 2009, Andris Piebalgs received the 'Diamond Prize' from the Regional Chamber of Commerce in Katowice (Poland) for his work in developing a cohesive European Energy Policy for the further generations.
In 2009, the Energy Efficiency Global Forum presented him the Energy Efficiency Visionary Awards for his 'outstanding contributions to the advancement of energy efficiency'.

He was twice appointed Acting Commissioner for Financial Programming and the Budget in Janusz Lewandowski's stead, from 19 April 2014 – 25 May 2014 while he was on electoral campaign leave for the 2014 elections to the European Parliament and from 1 July 2014 – 16 July 2014 after he took up his seat.

He was twice appointed Acting Commissioner for Financial Programming and the Budget in Janusz Lewandowski's stead, from 19 April 2014 – 25 May 2014 while he was on electoral campaign leave for the 2014 elections to the European Parliament and from 1 July 2014 – 16 July 2014 after he took up his seat.

On 15 November 2004 when questioned by the European Parliament as the Commissioner Designate for Energy, Piebalgs stressed the importance of environmental considerations in energy policy, and announced his intention to pursue a policy framework based on limiting growth in demand for energy while increasing diversity of supply.

Hearing of the Commissioner Designate for Development took place on 11 January 2010 in the European Parliament. During three hours members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from Committees of Development, Foreign Affairs and International Trade questioned him about his political priorities and key aims of development policy.
From 2012 to 2013, Piebalgs served – alongside Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, David Cameron and others – on the High-level Panel on Post-2015 Development Agenda
Latvian European Commissioner 2004–2014
European Commissioner for Energy 2004–2010
European Commissioner for Development 2010–2014
ERR. 5 June 2016. Retrieved 5 June 2016.
Archived from the original on 27 July 2020. Retrieved 27 July 2020.

Andris Piebalgs was born on 17 September 1957 in
Valmiera
, Latvia.

Earlier in his career, while Latvia was still part of the
Soviet Union
, Andris Piebalgs worked as a teacher and was the headmaster of the 1st Secondary School of Valmiera (1980–1990).

Andris Piebalgs was born on 17 September 1957 in
Valmiera
, Latvia.
He also served as director of the department in the Ministry of Education in Latvia.

Earlier in his career, while Latvia was still part of the
Soviet Union
, Andris Piebalgs worked as a teacher and was the headmaster of the 1st Secondary School of Valmiera (1980–1990).
one year later, in August 1991, Latvia regained full independence.
Andris Piebalgs first served as the ambassador of Latvia in Estonia (1995–1997),
From 2003 to 2004, he was appointed Deputy Secretary of State for EU affairs at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Latvia.
At the time, he also established the new development assistance policy for Latvia.
In addition to his native Latvian he is fluent in English, German, French, and Russian, and has basic knowledge of Estonian.
In addition to his native Latvian he is fluent in English, German, French, and Russian, and has basic knowledge of Estonian.

He was twice appointed Acting Commissioner for Financial Programming and the Budget in Janusz Lewandowski's stead, from 19 April 2014 – 25 May 2014 while he was on electoral campaign leave for the 2014 elections to the European Parliament and from 1 July 2014 – 16 July 2014 after he took up his seat.

He was twice appointed Acting Commissioner for Financial Programming and the Budget in Janusz Lewandowski's stead, from 19 April 2014 – 25 May 2014 while he was on electoral campaign leave for the 2014 elections to the European Parliament and from 1 July 2014 – 16 July 2014 after he took up his seat.

On 15 November 2004 when questioned by the European Parliament as the Commissioner Designate for Energy, Piebalgs stressed the importance of environmental considerations in energy policy, and announced his intention to pursue a policy framework based on limiting growth in demand for energy while increasing diversity of supply.

Hearing of the Commissioner Designate for Development took place on 11 January 2010 in the European Parliament. During three hours members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from Committees of Development, Foreign Affairs and International Trade questioned him about his political priorities and key aims of development policy.
